required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Popliteal Plexus Block on Pain After Total Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Popliteal Plexus Block on Postoperative Pain After Total Knee Arthroplasty

brief_summary.textblock: The study aims to investigate the effect of the Popliteal plexus block (PPB) on postoperative pain after total knee arthroplasty

detailed_description.textblock:
Cadaver dissection studies have shown a spread of dye to the popliteal fossa and colored the popliteal plexus by injecting in the distal part of the adductor Canal.
The popliteal plexus is formed by contribution from the tibial and the obturator nerves.
Investigators hypothesized that a PPB may reduce postoperative pain after total knee arthroplasty.

primary_outcome.measure: The percentage of patients with postoperative pain NRS
primary_outcome.description: Evaluated as the percentage of patients with postoperative pain NRS >3, dropping in pain score to NRS = or < 3 after the PPB

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients having a femoral triangle block(FTB) reporting NRS > 3
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pain scores every 15 minutes (from end injection FTB to NRS>3 or 3 hours after full sensation of the leg)
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of patients having a FTB, reporting postoperative pain NRS >3

secondary_outcome.time_frame: NRS every 5 minutes after PPB (From 0 - 60 minutes after PPB)
secondary_outcome.description: Time from end of injection of PPB to NRS = or < 3

secondary_outcome.measure: Turn off time of spinal anesthesia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time from arrival in PACU and during maximum 6 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Time from arrival in PACU to normal cutaneous sensation (measured by a neuro-pen, sensation=point 2) on the lateral part of the thigh and lateral part of the lower leg

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between normal cutaneous sensation and developing of pain
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From arrival in PACU and during maximum 6 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between normal cutaneous sensation (measured by a neuro-pen, sensation=point 2) and developing of pain (NRS>3)

secondary_outcome.measure: The effect of the PPB on cutaneous sensation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: NRS every 5 minutes after PPB (From 0 - 60 minutes after PPB)
secondary_outcome.description: Tested on the lateral part of the lower leg

secondary_outcome.measure: The effect of the PPB on muscle strength of the foot
secondary_outcome.description: Dorsal flexion and plantar flexion in the ankle joint, measured with a handheld dynamometer

arm_group.description: Patients with an FTB, reporting postoperative pain (NRS > 3) will have a popliteal plexus block
Patients with postoperative pain NRS < or = 3

intervention.description: Popliteal plexus block with 10 mL of bupivacaine-epinephrine 5 mg/mL + 5 microgram/mL.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty in spinal anesthesia
- age > or = 18 years
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) status I-III
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients unable to cooperate
- Patients not able to speak Danish
- Pregnancy
- Contraindication towards ana Medical product used in the study
- Preoperatively reduced sensation on the medial and lateral part of the lower leg
- Patients with diabetic requiring Medical treatment
- Preoperative daily intake of opioids
